abstract.p: Ned Ford letter on Jan 15 editorial says that although climate change warrants a regulatory approach soon, it is not strictly necessary to place limits on emissions of greenhouse gases; says alternative is to increase support rapidly for money-saving energy efficiency

Re ''New Players on Global Warming'' (editorial, Jan. 15):

Although climate change warrants a regulatory approach soon, it is not strictly necessary to place limits on emissions of greenhouse gases. The alternative is to increase support rapidly for money-saving energy efficiency.

A compact fluorescent bulb that saves more than $40 worth of electricity costs $5 today. A car that uses 40 percent less gasoline costs a couple of hundred dollars more than an identical car that has a more primitive engine. According to a recent report by the Department of Energy, adopting energy-efficient technologies could reduce American carbon emissions by about a third over the next 20 years in all sectors for less money than we presently spend. Other estimates are much higher.
It is possible to make steady significant reductions in energy use on the order of 2 percent a year, for several decades, before we run out of money-saving measures. It won't happen by accident.
